theme.title: Measures and Bar lines
theme.para: It is helpful to 'parcel up' the consecutive notes and rests into groups named 'measures' (in British English the word 'bar' is used instead of 'measure'). All measures have the same temporal duration and, as any piece of music has always a pulsating rythm, the 'measures' are always composed by a fixed number of 'beats'.

On the staff, the end of each measure is marked with a thin vertical line, drawn from the top line to the bottom line of the staff. This line is called a bar line. There are different types of bar lines, that are used for special purposes. For example, the end of the last measure of a piece of music is marked with a double bar line, being the fist line thin and the second one thick. The thin double bar line (two thin lines) is used to mark sections within a piece of music.

theme.para: Línea divisoria: encargada de delimitar los compases. Al final de la lección será más gruesa. Se llama 'doble barra'. Notas: do mi sol. Do es el sonido más grave de estos 3. Mi es el intermedio, y sol el más agudo.
